I know it's a big one." She said "twenty five dollars," which to a working man is not chicken feed. I produced the money and she put it in her shoe and pulled up her skirt. direction.raw_text: Well, I reckon what you're a wanting to know is what I'm doing in here. I reckon the reason I'm in here is 'cause I killed somebody. But I reckon what you was a wanting to know is how come me to kill somebody. Well, I reckon I'll start at the front and tell you. (pause, heavy breathing) I lived most of my life out behind my mother and father's house in a little old shed and my daddy'd built for me. They didn't too much want me up there in the house with the rest of 'em. I mostly just set around out there in the shed all the time a lookin' at the ground. It didn't have no floor but I had me a hole dug out to lay down in and a quilt or tow that I put down there. (pause, more breathing) My daddy was a hard workin' man most of his life, not that I can say the same fer myself. I most just set around the shed and tinkered around with a lawn mower or two and went to school off and on from time to time but the children there made quite a bit of sport of me, made fun of me quite a bit. Some of 'em roughed me up sometimes so mostly I stayed out back there in the shed. My daddy worked down at the sawmill there, down there at the planer mill for an old man named Dixon. Old man Dixon was a very cruel feller, he didn't treat his employees very well, didn't pay 'em much of a wage, didn't pay my daddy much of a wage, just barely enough to get by on. But I reckon he got by all right, they come out one or the other of 'em, usually my mother, and fed me pretty regular. At least I know he made enough for me to have mustard and biscuits three or four times a week. Old man Dixon had a boy named Jesse Dixon. Jesse was really more cruel than his daddy. He made quite a bit of sport of me and takened advantage of the little girls around the neighborhood quite a bit. (pause) He used to say my mother was a very pretty woman. He said it quite a bit from time to time, when I was at the school house. Well, I reckon you want me to get on and tell you what happened so I reckon I'll tell you. I was settin' out in the shed one evenin' not doin' too much, just kindly starin' at the wall and a waitin' fer my mother to come out and give me my Bible lesson and I heared a commotion up in the house there so I got up and run up on the screened-in porch there to see what was a goin' on, and I looked in the kitchen window and I seen my mother a layin' there on the floor without any clothes on. (pause, breathing) And seen Jesse Dixon a layin' on top of her having his way with her. (pause) Well, I just seen red. I picked up a kaiser blade that was a layin' there by the screen door, some folks calls it a sling blade, I call it a kaiser blade. It's just a long handle like a axe handle with a long blade on it that's shaped kind of like a banana. Sharp on one edge and dull on the other. It's what the highway boys use to cut down weeds and whatnot. I went in the kitchen there and I hit Jesse Dixon up side the head with it and knocked him off my mother. I reckon that didn't quite satisfy me so I hit him again in the neck with the sharp edge and just plumb near cut his head off. Killed him. Well, my mother, she jumped up from there and started yellin', "What did you kill Jesse fer? What did you kill Jesse fer?" (pause, intense breathing) Well, come to find out my mother didn't really mind what Jesse was a doin' to her. I reckon that made me madder than what Jesse had made me. I takened the kaiser blade, some folks calls it a sling blade, I call it a kaiser blade and hit my mother up side the head with it an' killed her. (long pause, breathing) Some folks has asked me if I had it to do over again would I do the same thing. I don't know, I reckon I would. Anyhow, they seen fit to put me in here and here I've been for a great long while. I've learned to read some; took me four years to read the Bible. I reckon I understand a good deal of it. It wasn't what I expected in a lot of places. I've slept in a good bed for a great long while. They've seen fit to put me out now. They tell me they're a settin' me free today. Anyhow, I reckon that's all you need to know. If you want any more details I reckon I can tell 'em to you. I don't know if that's enough for your newspaper or not. direction.raw_text: Jerry, why didn't you give him Bubba's room? Sister's is kind of girly, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I thought about that. No sense in moving him now I guess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daddy, don't you think one of us ought to stay up all night and kind of - guard or somethin'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, hell no, son. What's wrong with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, he's crazy. He's a nut ain't he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Isn't' he, Bubba. Don't say ain't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Woolridge, already dressed, walks through the den and down the hallway. He knocks on the bedroom door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl, you up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir. Woolridge opens the bedroom door and sees Karl sitting on the edge of the bed beside his books. The light is on, the bed still as it was the night before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't you go to sleep at all, Karl? You been sittin' there like that all night?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I guess we better hit the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Woolridge's car pulls into the parking lot. He and Karl get out and walk toward the shop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two men, BILL COX, a large man in his forties, and SCOOTER HODGES, a really country-looking guy in his thirties, look up from behind the counter as Woolridge and Karl enter. Woolridge goes to the counter, Karl stands by the door looking at the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey Jerry, how it's goin'. Good to see you. Been a long time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good to see you, Bill. How's everybody doin'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aw, pretty good. Kids are drivin' me crazy and Phyliss is gonna put me in the poorhouse. Can't complain other than that. Wouldn't do any good if I did. (laughs) Do you know Scooter, Jerry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, don't guess I do. (he shakes hands with Scooter who sort of smiles) Scooter, good to meet you. (Woolridge leans in and gets confidential) This is him, the one I talked to you about on the phone. Now like I said, I'll understand if you get nervous about it. I'm not gonna lie to you now, he did get in that trouble but then he was real young.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remember it real well. Cut them folks to pieces. His mama one of 'em.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that ol' Dixon boy. Hell, I always wanted to kill him myself. Asshole's what he was. I remember that ol' boy (points to Karl) too. Kind of retarded or somethin' back in school.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, he seems pretty well-adjusted these days. I don't think he'd ever hurt anybody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't look much like he could. You say he can fix a small engine like nobody's bidness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a regular whiz at it. That's all he did when he was a kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I ain't scared of him workin' here. You know me. I'm a church goin' man. Forgivin' man. When your time's up the Lord's gonna come git you. You seared of him, Scooter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't guess. Can he talk?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yeah. Listen I really appreciate it. He needs the job. I don't know what to do with him. He don't have anybody really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That old man of his still livin' over there on Clark Street I believe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He won't have anything to do with him. Now you say it's all right for him to stay out here in the back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine with me. If he steals anything, I'll take it out of your pocket anyway. Bill slaps Woolridge on the shoulders and wheezes with laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He won't steal. I'm tellin' you he's a pretty good ol' boy. Keeps to himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I've got a roomful of work for him to do. Can't get Scooter to do any of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl, come over here. I want you to meet your new boss. (Karl obediently shuffles over) This is Bill Cox, runs this place. Says you can work here and stay in the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good to know you, Karl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank ye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now it's minimal wage and there ain't nothin' but a army cot and a toilet back there. Karl doesn't say anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That'll be fine. Karl, I'll go to the car and get your books. Woolridge exits. Bill and Scooter just stare at Karl and Karl stares at the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They say you're a whiz on fixin' lawn mowers and things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've tinkered around on 'em a little bit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We order from Dairy Queen at noontime usually. We can buy your lunch till you get on your feet a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like them french-fried potaters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, me too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They make a good double meat burger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The place is cluttered with mowers, edgers, weed-eaters, and other equipment, most of it in pieces. A small cot is in a little clearing in the corner by the bathroom. Karl is sweeping up oil with sawdust and a push broom while Scooter puts some tools away. Bill comes to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right then, I'll see y'all later. Karl you done a good day's work. They right about you. Scooter, he's gonna knock you out of a job if you're not careful. I'll see you tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait up, I'll leave with you and lock up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl, they's a blanket up in under that cot and soap in the bathroom to clean up with. (pause) Now there's one more thing. The way we lock these doors at night, you can't get out. You didn't want to go anywhere, did you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't reckon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it works out and all, maybe we'll get you a key so you can get out at night if you need to. See you later. They leave Karl standing in the midst of the lawn mowers. He sets the broom down and goes and sits on the cot. After a moment, he gets back up and starts sweeping again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's lunch time and Bill, Scooter, and Karl are sitting in folding chairs behind the counter eating from their Dairy Queen to-go bags. Karl has french fries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scooter, did I tell about the two old boys pissin' off the bridge?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't remember.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was these two old boys hung their peckers off of a bridge to piss, one old boy from California and one old boy from Arkansas. Old boy from California says, "Boy this water's cold." Old boy from Arkansas says "Yeah, and it's deep too." (starts wheezing) Get it? That's a goodun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, that's a goodun. I believe you did tell me that one before. I've heard that a bunch. Long time ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, yeah it's a classic. You know, Karl, I got to thinkin' about it last night and it's just not Christian of me to not let you have a key. I mean you been in lockup so long, you don't need me keepin' you locked up. You need to come and go as you please. Here, take this key, it'll get you in and out that back door. (Karl takes the key and keeps eating french fries) Them french fries good?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, they's good all right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got any money?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They give me fifty dollars when they turned me loose. I spent up some of it on ridin' the bus and eatin' french-fried potaters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm gonna pay you today for this comin' week, so you'll have some walkin' around money. When you get off this evenin' you better go buy some toothpaste and cleanin' up supplies to have back there. Some hard candy and some magazines. Somethin' to keep you busy at night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll let you off while it's still daylight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl is walking down a residential street. He stops in front of the house where the boy, Frank, lives and stares at the house for a moment, then he walks up to the door and stares at it. A curtain moves and the boy's face appears at the window. He comes and opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey there. I thought I heard somebody on the porch. Wasn't your name Karl?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah it is. Your name's Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. What you doin' by here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You told me to come by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you want to play ball with us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ain't no good at it. I just come by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, anyhow, I was just fixin' to go see my mama down at Ben's Dollar Store. She's workin' two till eight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right then. He starts to walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a minute. You want to go with me? You can meet my mama.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to worry your mama with company.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aw, come on. You'll like her. She's real nice. She'll give us somethin' if we ask her to. Candy or somethin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was kindly needin' to do some tradin'. Reckon they sell toothpaste?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They sell some of everything. Come on let's go. I won't tell her about you bein' in the state hospital for killin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank and Karl make their way through the fairly crowded store. It's sort of a mini-version of a Walmart. They find Frank's mother in her red smock talking to a guy in a red Ben's knit shirt. They are laughing together and pricing some mouthwash. LINDA WHEATLEY is a short, plain woman in her thirties. The man, VAUGHAN CUNNINGHAM, is in his forties, with a neat flattop hair cut, glasses, and a paunch hanging over his belt. They eye Karl suspiciously, as the boys approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Mama. Hey, Vaughan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, sweetheart. What you up to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me guess. You want a bunch of candy and a pop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're gonna rot your teeth that way. But I bet I know what you would like even better. I put potted meat on special, four cans for a dollar and they're not moving very well. I'd sure let a few cans go for free to the right boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't like potted meat. Daddy used to say it was made out of lips and peckers and intestints.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank, don't talk that way. Who's that strange lookin' man behind you? Did he follow you in here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I help you, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, that's Karl. I met him at the laundrymat. Karl, this is my mama. And Vaughan, Vaughan's the manager. He lets mama off any time she feels like it 'cause they're best friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice to meet you, Karl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pleased to know y'all. There's an uncomfortable silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank come back here with me for a minute. She shuffles him away and leaves Vaughan staring at Karl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think I've ever seen you before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naw, I don't believe you have. I don't reckon I never been in here. This store didn't used to be here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's been here seventeen years. Did you live here before or something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I's horned and raised here up till I's twelve year old.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What brings you back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that you say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you here now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They turned me loose from the state hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that right? (pause) Are you going to be staying here long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I reckon Mr. Woolridge got me hired on to work for Bill Cox's outfit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have family here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not really to speak of. Linda and Frank return from the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey Karl, guess what. Mama said you can stay with us. Out in the garage. Our car won't fit in there anyway. It's real neat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank told me about your situation. And Frank loves company. You know, especially after his daddy passed and all. There ain't no sense in you stayin' in that old greasy shop. (to Vaughan, hushed) He's mentally retarded, poor thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He just got out of the state hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can we get some candy and pops?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, go ahead. They walk off down the aisle leaving Vaughan a little puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you sure it's safe to let him around that guy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank's just crazy about him. He likes the way he talks. He helped him carry home the clean laundry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's been in the state hospital a long time, something must be wrong with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's retarded's all. You know he's always after a father figure and Lord knows Doyle ain't a good one with his mean ass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think he sees you as a guy guy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl is a guy guy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl and Frank sit on stumps in a little clearing enjoying the spoils of their Ben's Dollar Store visit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is what I call my secret place 'cause I come out here when I feel like bein' by myself. I used to come here with Karen Cross. She's kind of like my girlfriend, or used to be. She says she likes Jerry Maroney now. But I'm gonna get her back 'cause I love her. We used to come here and hold hands and talk and read books to each other with a flashlight. She didn't want to have anything to do with me in front of other people 'cause I don't have any money. Well, mama and me, I mean. She seemed to like me a whole lot when we were out here though. She said she loved me, too. Out here. Settin' right on that stump you're on. See, her daddy's a dentist so they're rich. So's Jerry Maroney's daddy. He owns the ice plant. Was your folks well off?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naw. Didn't have too much. Enough to scrape by on, I reckon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They still around, your folks?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother's dead. My daddy's s'posed to be around still. He don't want to have nothin' to do with me though.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He never did want to. I figure he ain't changed his mind much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did your mama die?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't need to know all of that. You're just a boy. You need to think about good thoughts while you're still a boy. They'll be plenty of time for the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've had a lot of bad thoughts since my daddy died. Sometimes I wish I was still real little and he was still here. My mama's real good, but I wish I had both of 'em. (pause) When we went to Memphis one time in the car, it was rainin' so hard we couldn't see the road. But I wadn't scared because I thought as long as daddy was drivin' nothin' could happen to us. I feel that way about mama now. (he looks at the ground for a moment) Mama has a boyfriend now. His name is Doyle Hargraves. He works construction so he makes a pretty good livin'. He still don't help mama out with any money though. He ain't no good. He's mean to her. He don't like me at all. Mama says it's because he's jealous I belong to my daddy instead of him. He stays with us all night sometimes, but he's got his own house. Somebody told me it's so he can still have other girlfriends. I like it on the nights when he ain't at our house. I'm not so nervous then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How come her to keep bein' girlfriends and all with him if he's mean to her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She says it's for the times when he's good to her. She's lonely since daddy died. She said sometimes she don't know why. (pause) He threatened to kill her if she ever left him. My daddy would kill him if he was here and somebody was mean to mama. Vaughan, he's real good to mama. Vaughan that you met. But he's not able to do anything to Doyle, he's funny you know. Not funny ha, ha, funny queer. He likes to go with men instead of women. That makes him not to be able to fight too good. He sure is nice though. He's from St. Louis. People who are queer can get along better in a big town. He got transferred here to work. But mama said the real reason he left is 'cause his daddy hated him. For bein' the way he is. I wish he liked to go with women. I'd rather him be mama's boyfriend than Doyle. Pause as Frank looks at the ground again. He seems troubled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl. (pause) You know when I said daddy got hit by a train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I remember you a-tellin' me that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It ain't the truth. He shot hisself with a shotgun on purpose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did he do that, reckon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Cause he didn't have enough money to take care of us the way he wanted to. That's what the letter said. He got laid off from work and had to just work odd jobs. I thought he took care of us fine. (pause) Karl, did you really kill somebody?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who did you kill?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were they bad people?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought they was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe they needed it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I growed up and got taught it ain't right to kill nobody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay if you're lookin' out for yourself. If it's self-defense. Was it self-defense? Karl shifts around and makes a noise in his throat and doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My daddy was good. I think too many good people die. It ain't right. That's what I think.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl is tying the strap around his books. His sack of toiletries is on the bed. Bill Cox comes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, Karl, you sure you want to go stay with these folks? You're welcome to keep on stayin here. It's workin' out real good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That boy wants me to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right then. I'll see you bright and early. How you comin' along on that garden tiller?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I fixed it. Hit's a workin' pretty good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You done fixed it? I'll be damned. Scooter told me it couldn't be fixed. 'Course Scooter's about as shitless as one poor son-of-a-bitch can be. You done fixed it. I'll just be damned. See you tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is in the comfortable easy chair with adjuster handle drinking beer. He's in his late thirties and dressed in his construction clothes. Linda sits on the arm of the chair and Frank stands before them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, honey, I don't guess I give a shit. I ain't here half the time anyway. If you want a retard livin' in the garage, I don't guess I care. I've got a good tool box and socket set out there I don't want stol'd. I guess I could take it home with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's real honest. He wouldn't steal nothin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now son, I wadn't talkin' to you, was I? (pause) Was I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No sir's right. I'm talkin' to your mama. This is your mama's decision, not yours. I'm lettin' it go on because she asked me, not you. (to Linda) Now is this the kind of retard that drools and rubs shit in his hair and all that, 'cause I have trouble eatin' around that kind of thing. Just like I am about antique furniture and midgets. I can't so much as drink a glass of water around a midget or a piece of antique furniture. Same thing with a droolin' retard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle, you're awful. You shouldn't be that way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ain't sayin' it's right. I'm just tellin' the truth. What was he in the nuthouse for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's just mentally retarded, I guess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He had of went nuts and did somethin'. They don't put you in there for just bein' a retard. They's retards all over the place that ain't in the nuthouse. Do you know, Frank?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ain't sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You might want to find out. He might of hacked his family to pieces with a hatchet or somethin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, that's right, Frank, you better ask him. I mean, don't hurt his feelin's or anything, but it would be good to know. I'm sure it's nothin'. He seems real sweet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sure are hung up on people bein' sweet. (takes a long pull on his beer) Speakin' of which, where's your girlfriend? I thought he was comin' by here for something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll be here in a little while, he's takin' me to get an ice cream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ain't that the sweetest thing. What am I supposed to do about supper with you traipsin' around with that fag?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not crippled. Get in there and make somethin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy, ain't you somethin' else. Talkin' back and everything. It kinda makes me horny when you talk back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank, why don't you go off and play in your room if Doyle's gonna talk nasty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to watch T.V.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, honey, let the kid watch T.V. Hell, let's all watch T.V. like a family till your retarded friend and your homosexual friend gets here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl is standing on the porch with his bag and his books staring at the door. After a moment, we hear a car door slam and footsteps on the porch. Then we hear Vaughan's voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl? Karl turns to face Vaughan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, you're really going to stay here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That boy wants me to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you knock on the door yet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naw, I ain't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long have you been standing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quite a spell, I reckon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, before you get very used to staying here, I think you and I need to talk about a few things. Can I take you to lunch?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I done et just a little bit ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean tomorrow or the next day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I reckon I can stand to eat a little somethin' or 'nother at noontime tomorrow. Bill Cox generally gets me a box of french fried potaters. But I reckon he can lay off doin' it tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, I'll come by Mr. Cox's and get you at noon. They stand therefor a moment. Vaughan doesn't really know exactly what else to do, so he knocks on the door. After a moment, Frank answers the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey. Y'all come on in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughan ushers Karl in and they stand behind the sofa. Doyle looks up and grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Vaughan. How are you, Karl?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tolerable, I reckon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl, this is my boyfriend, Doyle. Frank, why don't you and Karl go out in the garage and fix him up a place or play a game or somethin'. Vaughan, you ready to go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, I guess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't rush ever'body, honey. She starts to get her things together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe you and Karl want to go with us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naw, I don't want to. Me and Karl got things we need to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Vaughan, you know what I heard? I heard you been puttin' it to Albert Sellers that works over at the funeral home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know Albert. We're friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard you was more than friends. I heard Dick Rivers caught y'all all bowed up and goin' at it in the same room with poor, little, old Mizz Ogletree and her dead as a doornail layed out on a gurney.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's ridiculous. That's just a total lie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go, Vaughan. (they start for the door) Frank, we'll be back in a little while. I'll bring you back somethin'. You're food's in the oven warmin' over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See, you made him somethin'. Hey Vaughan, I was just goin' on with you, jokin' around, buddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I knew that. You're a card all right. Linda kisses Frank on the forehead and they leave.
direction.name: direction
