direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you, too, Mama. He goes to his room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Linda goes into the kitchen and pours a cup of coffee and sits at the table. After a moment, she looks up and is startled to see Karl in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You scared me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't aim to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want to sit down? Did you need somethin'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No ma'am. Karl just keeps standing there and Linda keeps staring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two fellers was on a bridge a takin' a leak and one feller says the water was cold and the other said it was deep water. One of 'em came from Arkansas, I believe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be dog. More silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you reckon you can make me some biscuits?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just whenever you take a notion to. I don't aim to put you out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it is nearly breakfast time anyway. I can't go to sleep. I have to be at work in three hours. You know how it is when you just sleep an hour or two, you feel worse than if you hadn't slept at all?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes ma'am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, set down and I'll make some biscuits and gravy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mustard's good on 'em to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Karl sets at the table and Linda starts to make the biscuits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank ye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all right. (pause) You know I was thinkin' there's this girl that works with me. She's real heavy, but she's cute in the face. Well, you know, she's slow. She's a little bit, I think. She's not retarded, just -- it don't matter, listen to me. I thought you might like to meet her. Vaughan wants to have a little supper over at his house and we could invite her. Would you like that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't mind a havin' supper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughan's "friend" will be there, too. He works at the funeral home. And Frank. You know Frank likes you a lot. He says you make him feel calm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like Frank. He's a good boy. Me and him's made friends. She keeps working.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hit ain't right for me to keep from tellin' you how come me to be put in the state hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's okay. It's not really my business. I have wondered though. Why was it? Was it like a nervous breakdown?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I killed my mother and a old boy name Jesse Dixon. I thought they was a-doin' wrong. I was about your boy's age. They say I'm well now from it. Linda stops working and turns to Karl, a little shocked, but not as much as you would think.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was that you? I remember that. I was only three or four, but I always heard about it growin' up. (pause) They say you're well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes ma'am. (pause) I like your garage. (pause) I wouldn't never hurt you or your boy. I'd lay my hand on the Bible and say the same thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe you. I really do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill Cox is standing beside a garden tiller with an old man. Bill is trying to crank it up, but it won't start. A car pulls into the parking lot and Gerry Woolridge gets out of it and comes over to Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How 'bout you, Jerry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are you, Bill?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doin' pretty good. Got a sick tiller here. What's got you down this way?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just thought I'd check on Karl and see if everything's working out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, he's pretty quiet. Except for them rackets and breathin' things he does. Ain't threatened me with a killin' or anything. (laughs) But boy you couldn't of been more right about him fixin' things. That son of a bitch is a regular Eli Whitney on a lawnmower. Loves french fries. Eats four larges and don't even so much as belch. I'm proud to have him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is him stayin' here workin' out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's gone to stayin' over with that Wheatley boy and his mama in their garage. I think that little boy adopted him damn near like a mascot. But he's got a key here to come and go as he pleases. Everything's worked out good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I see him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. Bill looks over at Scooter, who is putting up a sale sign on new mowers in the front window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scooter! Run get Karl for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Woolridge and Karl lean on the hood of Woolridge's car. In the background, Bill and the old man tinker with the tiller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you sure you're okay staying with that woman and boy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do they know about you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My history.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told 'em about it. They know I'm well. That Mizz Wheatley made me some biscuits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That boy, he's my friend. He likes the way I talk and I like the way he talks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew you'd do all right. Well, I just wanted to check on you. I'll say bye to Bill and get on back. They walk over to Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl, see if you can figure out what's wrong with this thing. It won't crank up and ever'thing seems to be put together right. Karl squats beside the tiller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll see you, Bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, stop back by. Don't worry about your boy here, he's doin' good. Karl looks up from the tiller holding the gas cap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hit ain't got no gas in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See there. Thinks of the simplest thing first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughan, ALBERT the "friend," Linda, Frank, Karl, and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the Dollar-Store girl, are seated at the table. Karl and Frank are going at the delicacies while Melinda shyly picks at hers and the others are engaged in idle chit chat. This goes on for a few moments, then Albert's attention turns to Karl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So Karl, do you intend to stay in the lawnmower business for a while or do you have other plans?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I reckon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think Karl is going to be a writer or a librarian eventually. You should see all the books he has. He must read constantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ain't read 'em yet except two or three of 'em. I can't understand a lot of what I try to read. My mind, hit wonders off to somethin' else when I try to read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm the same way. Of course, in my line of work, I stay too busy to read. But at least I have job security. People may stop doing a lot of things, but one thing is for sure, they won't stop dying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't we talk about something a little more festive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does everyone like the food? Nods and yeses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. I haven't decided yet if I'm a good cook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey Karl, you know what? Melinda was voted employee of the month at the Dollar Store last February. Isn't that somethin'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes ma'am, I reckon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, when you like pricing items as much as I do, I guess it's just bound to happen sooner or later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl, maybe you and Melinda might want to take a walk or something after dinner. It's a nice night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughan, don't get pushy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like walkin' quite a bit from time to time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I stay on my feet all the time at work. I just can't find shoes that's comfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hospital shoes might be the answer. Nurses' shoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or the kind old ladies who work in the school cafeteria wear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Same difference.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I get real mean when my feet hurt. It's the only time I don't like checkin' out the customers, when my feet hurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank, you and Karl aren't talkin' much, you boys must really like that food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just don't have anything to say about shoes. Silence for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen everybody, I know this may sound corny, I've had a few glasses of wine and that kind of makes me a little emotional, but I'm going to say it anyway. It just came over me in a rush. I want you all to know that I care about each and every one of you at this table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's very sweet of you Vaughan. We care about you, too. Don't we y'all? Nods, grunts, "Sure do's."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Also, Melinda, please don't tell anybody at the store that Albert was here tonight, okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, a lot of people in town talk and spread cruel rumors. Unfortunately, I have to keep certain parts of my life private.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean about y'all bein' together in "that" way?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think everybody at the store knows that already. They always talk about it. Maureen Ledbetter told a awful story about why you ain't allowed over at the First Baptist Church no more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl, why don't you and Melinda go take a walk. It's nice out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right then. He gets up and walks toward the front door. Melinda gets up and tries to catch up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl and Melinda are walking in the moonlight. It seems a little hard for Melinda to keep up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You walk fast, don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I reckon. They walk a little farther in silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These is the worst shoes I own for walkin'. How far did you want to go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ain't really thought about it too much I don't reckon. They walk until they disappear into the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl is on the floor working on a mower with Scooter, they are ad libbing semi-technical lawnmower things. Bill Cox appears in the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey Karl, they's somebody out here to see you. Some gal holding a nice bouquet. (Karl doesn't move) Come on now, she wants to talk to you. Don't just set there. Karl gets up and goes to the counter followed by Scooter. Melinda stands on the other side of the counter holding a cellophane wrapped store-bought flower assortment. Nobody says anything for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Karl, I'm on lunch break. These was on sale 'cause they're not fresh. Two ninety-nine a bunch plus my ten percent employee discount. Since I didn't bring you anything to our date last night, I thought you'd like to have 'em. She hands them to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank ye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scooter, let's me and you go over to Dairy Queen and pick up a few things for lunchtime.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can go. You don't have to. You don't never go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goddamnit, Scooter, come on. Pardon my language, ma'am. They start to leave. At the door, Bill Cox turns and winks at Karl. They exit leaving Karl and Melinda staring at the counter. They are silent for a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I just thought I'd give you them. I liked walkin' with you. I got a blister the size of a quarter on one heel. Well, I'll see you sometime, I guess. She walks to the door and stops as if she expects Karl to say something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A blister shore can hurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flowers is pretty. I've always thought that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me, too. She leaves and Karl goes to the window holding the flowers and watches her walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holding the flowers, Karl is walking down the sidewalk toward the Wheatley house when he sees Frank coming out the front door with a book and a flashlight. He sees Karl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey Karl, you off work?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where'd you get them flowers?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That gal that made employee of the month give 'em to me for awalkin' with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was goin' to the secret place. I borried one of your books to take down there. You ain't mad, are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naw. You can look at all my books you want to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's name's A Christmas Carol.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's than un on Christmas I was tellin' you about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want to go with me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SECRET PLACE - NIGHT Karl and Frank sit in the clearing, Karl on the stump, Frank on the ground. Frank is shining the flashlight on the book. He finishes reading a few lines and turns off the flashlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm gettin' tired of readin' for a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy, folks sure had it rough back a long time ago, didn't they?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I reckon they did. Hit like to tore me up when I read about that pore little cripple boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, me too. (pause) That was nice of that woman to give you them flowers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hit was right thoughty of her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was wantin' to ask you somethin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know that girl I told you about. The one I love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I recollect it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you go see her with me? I kind of thought I might take her some flowers like that woman done you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you want me to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ain't got no money to get 'em with but I bet Vaughan will let me have some of them flowers at the store.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I bet he will. I got a little money if he don't. I'll get 'em for ye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I usually get run off by her mama or daddy if they're home. Reckon why they don't like me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They ort to. You're a good boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just 'cause I'm not rich don't mean I don't love her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naw.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I don't try to touch her. You know, in a bad way. Foolin' around, sex and all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's real good. You ort not to if ye ain't married to somebody. Bible tells you that much. Hit tells some things that don't seem right too, I reckon. I guess a feller ort to foller it close as he can, though. (pause) You don't touch yourself, do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pull on your works. Your privates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, jackin' off?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir. You ort not know that language.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't know till here while back a year or two ago when I spent the night with Ronnie Smart one time. He said just tug on your peter and think about your mama. I tried it, but I felt funny thinkin' about my mama. So, I switched over to thinkin' about his mama and then what he told me would happen, happened. It sure tingles, don't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ort not to pull on yourself that away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I kind of like you tellin' me what to do and not to do. Just like my daddy. I didn't mind him tellin' me. I hate Doyle to tell me what to do. Mama said the only way to ever get away from him is for him to get away from us. That we can't leave him or he'll try and hurt her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He ain't no count.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't seem like a daddy. You seem like a brother. (pause) Wonder what makes you like somebody right off when you don't even know 'em like what happened with me and you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't reckon I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then some people you don't like right off. It's funny. (pause) You know why I want you to play ball with me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naw.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Cause it's fun. It don't matter if you ain't no good. It takes your mind off of everything else while you're doin' it. When you run real fast tryin' to make a touchdown you don't think about anything else. I ain't no good, but my daddy always said he was proud of me when I threw a ball or ran with it. Did you have any brothers and sisters growin' up to play with?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had one there for little bit. Hit didn't get old enough to play with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not? It died?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hit was borned a little too early on. My mother and father made hit come too early some way or other. I reckon they changed their mind about havin' another'n. I was about six or eight year old then and they didn't care too much for me so I reckon they didn't need somethin' else to worry 'em with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So it died when it come out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My daddy come to the shed out back and got me and said throw this here away and handed me a towel with somethin' in it. I went for the trash barrel there and opened up the towel to see 'cause they was a noise and somethin' movin' in it. Hit was bloody-like around that towel. Hit was a little ol' bitty baby, no bigger than a squirrel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was alive?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir. Right then it was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A boy or girl?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little ol' boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You threw it in a trash barrel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't feel right about doin' that. I takened a shoe box from there in the shed and emptied out some screwdrivers and nuts and warshers from it and put the little feller in that and buried him in the corner of the yard there. That seemed more proper to me, I reckon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was still alive when you buried it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heared it cryin' a little through that box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That don't seem right. It seems like you should have kept him alive and took care of him if he was your brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wadn't but six or eight. I reckon I didn't know what to do. I didn't know how to care for no baby. Mama and Daddy didn't want him. They learned me to do what they told me to. These days I figure it might of been best to give him right back to the Good Lord right off the bat anyhow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That makes me feel real sad. Couldn't you have done somethin', Karl? I would have. I wish I would of had him. He'd be here right now. Livin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hits been hard thinkin' about it. They ain't a day goes by I don't think about it. I kindly have a picture of it up in my head that I see. Hit makes me sad, too. I have bad thoughts on it. I wished they was somethin' I could of did, too. Shouldn't no bad things happen to childern. All the ol' bad things ort to be saved up for folks that's growed up, the way I see it. I shouldn't of told you about that. A boy ort not hear about such things. It just kindly come out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't mean to say anything bad about you. I know you're good. You didn't mean no harm. (pause) Did you ever think about killin' yourself on purpose like my daddy did?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've studied about it. The Bible says not to or you end up goin' to Hades. Some folks calls it Hell, I call it Hades.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bible says the same thing about killin' others, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir, I reckon it does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank, flowers in hand, and Karl approach a very nice two story house. They get to the door and Frank rings the doorbell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I always get nervous when I hear that doorbell. I'm okay just walkin' over, but somethin' about that dang doorbell. They have one room where you can't walk on the carpet or sit on the furniture. I don't see much sense in havin' it. The door opens and we see an older black lady, the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Son, I don't know why you keep comin' over here. You know these folks don't want you here. They run you off ever' time. Don't keep doin' this to yourself. You a sweet boy. Now go give them flowers to somebody that'll enjoy 'em.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ma'am, I really want to give them to Karen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You his daddy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No ma'am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, whoever you are, you ought to talk some sense into him. That little old girl is way too fast for him and don't wanna see him no way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you get her for me. Please. I really want to see her. She'll want to see me, too, 'cause we're not in public. Just don't tell her folks I'm here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. She disappears and a moment later KAREN appears. She's thirteen, pretty and very neatly dressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey Frank. You shouldn't be coming over here. My parents really don't want you to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to bring you some flowers. They're pretty good ones.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're from the Dollar Store. I'm not an idiot. Besides we have a garden full of flowers. She eyes Karl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted for you to meet Karl, too. He's my new friend. But I feel like I've always known him. I thought you should meet him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why? Hi, Karl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's gonna be around a lot and I hope you are too, so...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here give me the flowers, I'll do something with them. Thank you. Now you better go. Maybe I'll see you down at the secret place one day in a week or two or something. I have a boyfriend now you know. And we're pretty serious. He gave me a ring. She proudly displays the ring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you go there with us now? Me and Karl. We could just hang out. Karl has some cool books.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank, I just like you as a friend. Only at the secret place. Okay? I can't go there now. I'll see you later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But maybe just for awhile -- KAREN I'm closing the door now. I told you, I'll see you later. She closes the door. They stand therefor a moment, then walk away down the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She said she'd see me later. That's kinda good, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I reckon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank and Karl walk up the steps to the house. Frank opens the door and they enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Frank and Karl enter, they see Doyle sitting on a footstool facing Linda who's in a chair. Doyle is holding both her hands and talking very softly to her. He sees the guys and looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'll be damned, there's the boys. I'm glad y'all came in. I wanted to talk to y'all, too. I was just tellin' Linda here -- Oh hell, I'll just start over, set down you boys. They do, on the couch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, what it is is, I just, well I took off work early today and your mama was good enough to do the same so we could talk. I guess you'd say I'm really here to apologize, which ain't easy for me to do, about the way I acted the other night. I was just drunk and kinda got a little too worked up and one thing led to another. I care about y'all a lot, I do. I don't mean to be so damned, assholish I guess the word would be. Now Karl, I don't believe I hit you, did I? So no apology needed there I guess, but Frank, I'm sorry. I'm sorry I hit your mama. I'm just jealous of her. I don't like her life or the way she runs it. I don't like homosexuals and she buddies with one. I don't like little wimpy ass kids or fuckin' mental retards and she's got one of each livin' with her. (laughs) I was just kiddin'. But really I guess people need to get along even if they have differences. (pause) You see, I work construction. I build things. Do you realize how important that is to the world. I have a lot of pressure on me. The upshot is, I'm gonna spend a lot more time over here and we're gonna get along. Like a family should. (to Linda) I may even surprise you one day and pop the question. (he gets up) Well, I'm goin' back to work. I just wanted to give y'all some little piece of happiness today. (kisses Linda) See you tonight honey. Karl. Be a good boy, Frank. He leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, at least he's tryin'. But who knows for how long.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's lyin' Mama. He ain't gonna do better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know honey. Just remember what I said, we'll bide our time. You just steer clear of him as much as you can. Doyle's had a real hard life. It's just about run him crazy I think.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've had a real hard life, too, Mama. Linda moves to the couch and puts her arms around Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a hell of a boy, Frank. Someday you're gonna get all the good things you deserve. And Karl here's gonna get some more biscuits tonight. What do you think about that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could shore use some. Thank ye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl is cleaning some parts in a bucket of gasoline. Bill comes to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey there Karl, can you come unload a generator for me? Karl wipes his hands on a shop towel and starts outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and a TEENAGE BOY stand by a pickup truck. A small generator is on the tailgate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl, lift this thing down and carry it to the back. It's on the blink. (to man as Karl unloads it) We'll have it for you in a day or two, Walter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Y'ont us to he'p you there liftin' that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no, that dang Karl can lift a bulldozier. Fix anything, too. (confidentially) He's mentally retarded, but he's a whiz on small engines. Lord works in mysterious ways. Karl carries the generator toward the shop. He turns and watches the man and boy talking and laughing with Bill. The man playfully puts an arm around his son's neck and tousles his hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell, he didn't just make the team, Coach says he's probably gonna start at end on defense. He's a chip off the old block. Ain't you, Steve?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess so. Karl turns and goes in the shop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl is on his cot reading a book. Frank comes in. He looks very depressed. He sits beside Karl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What you readin'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Readin' on this book on how to work carpentry. I aim to learn how to build things out of wood one of these times. I've always been partial to wood buildin's and cabinets and whatnot. These drawin's they got here don't make no sense to me so far. (he looks directly at Frank, which he seldom does) You seem like yore tails a'draggin' a might. You got somethin' wrong with ye?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seems like Doyle's wormed his way back in. Mama said he's stayin' over tonight and he's talkin' about movin' in for good. We ain't ever gonna be happy. We'll always be nervous, won't we Karl?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't reckon I know. I ain't found no way yet and I'm three or four times as old as you. Might be that's just the way folks is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I feel sad about Karen Cross, too. I just make like to myself she loves me. I know better, though. It just feels good to me when I imagine it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make believin' always made me feel good too from time to time. They sit in silence for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill Cox is goin' to a funeral for a Mister Turner tomorrow and a closin' up shop early.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll play ball with ye. I reckon if neither one of us is no count it won't make no difference.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will? For sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll be on teams, me and you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yessir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the practice field, so it's not very well kept. Karl, Frank, and two other boys around Frank's age are huddled up. Four boys are lined on defense. They break the huddle and come to the line. They are on about the fifty-yard line. Frank hikes the ball to one of the boys. He later als it to Karl who stands there for a minute as the defenders run toward him. Then he takes off like the wind. He runs funny, kind of humped over and pigeon-toed, but fast. All the others are chasing him. Two of the other team's boys catch him on about the fifteen-yard line, but he drags them along. Karl sees Frank out of the corner of his eye and tosses him the ball just as Karl bites the dirt. Frank goes into the end zone untouched. There are cheers from Frank and the other boys. Frank runs over to Karl who's still on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Way to go, Karl. We got a touchdown. That was a good lateral, man. That was just like the Wishbone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I dern near had me a touchdown till them boys got a-hold of me there so I figured I better give it off to you. I seen you over there follerin' me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're liable to win if we keep this up. For somebody like you, you sure run fast. He grabs Karl by the hands and helps pull him up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, let's kick off to 'em.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl and Frank, dirt, grass stains and all, walk toward home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you could of scored them three touchdowns by yourself instead of throwing 'em over to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Them boys was tryin' to pull me down pretty hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're strong though. You let me make them touchdowns so I'd feel good. My daddy used to do that kind of thing. They walk in silence for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It don't matter to me about us losin' does it to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was fun, anyhow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wadn't thinkin' about nothin' else just like you told me I'd do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can we play ever' Saturday?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I ain't too stove up. I ain't like you. I'm old and give out. (pause) I'm proud of ye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl sits on his bed rubbing his hands together, deep in thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl is walking down the street past rundown houses. He comes to an old gray woodframe house. It is in bad repair, the paint is peeling, the yard is grown up. There is an old wooden shed in the back yard. He stands looking at it for a moment then walks through the yard and opens the door to the shed. He's motionless for a moment, then goes inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sunlight comes through the cracks in the wood. The shed has nothing but dirt for a floor. A few tall patches of grass shoot up between boxes and rusty lawnmowers. A few old garden tools hang on the wall. In the center is a low circular spot in the ground and a few tattered shreds of an old quilt. Karl stands looking at the hole for a moment, then turns and walks out of the shed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl walks across the yard to the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl goes onto the screened-in porch, looks through the kitchen window and goes inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The place is a mess. Dirty dishes are piled in the sink and on the table. It's not just clutter, but filth everywhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl walks into an equally filthy living room where an OLD MAN in overalls sits slumped in a chair looking at his lap. Karl stands facing him for several moments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm ye boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ain't got no boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm ye oldest boy name Karl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ain't got no boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They turned me aloose from the nervous hospital. Said I was well. No response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got hired to work for a Mr. Cox fixin' lawnmowers and whatnot. No response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That grass out in the yard's all growed up. I figured I might cut it fer ye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you, I ain't got no boy, now get on out from here and let me be. Long silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I learned to read some. I've read on the Bible quite a bit. I don't understand all of it, but I believe I understand a good deal of it. Them stories Mama and you told me ain't in there. You ort not to of done that to ye boy. (pause) I've studied on killin' you. But I don't reckon they's no reason fer it if all you're gonna do is set there in that chair. You'll be dead soon enough I reckon and the world'll be shut of ye. (Karl walks toward the kitchen and turns back to the old man) You ort not to of killed my brother. He ort to have had a chance to grow up. Sometimes he would of had fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl walks out of the house and across the yard to a hedge in the corner and kneels down. He pushes some grass aside to reveal a rock about afoot tall and afoot across. In front of it, the ground is raised a little. He stares at the rock for a moment and touches it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Little feller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl stands on the side of the bridge looking into the river below.
direction.name: direction

location: A LARGE OLD WOODEN SLAT BRIDGE
result.heading: EXT.

direction.raw_text: All the lights are out. We see a shot of Frank in his bed asleep, but tossing and turning. Then a shot of Linda in bed staring at the ceiling and Doyle beside her snoring. Suddenly, the lights come on and Linda lets out a little yelp and sits up, which wakes up Doyle and he sits up with a start. From their P.O.V. we see Karl standing in the door holding a hammer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What in the goddamn hell are you doin'? It's the middle of the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want, hun?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to be baptized.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Baptized? Well, get baptized then. I don't give a shit. Call a fuckin' preacher, goddamnit! I can't baptize you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll go to church and get you baptized, tomorrow's Sunday. You go on back to bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doin' with that damn hammer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't rightly know. I just kindly woke up a-holdin' it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see a shot of Frank and Linda and Vaughan in a church pew. The church is pretty full. From their P.O.V. we seek Karl in a robe standing in the baptismal tank. The preacher takes Karl and dunks him under the water and brings him back up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle is in his favorite chair as Linda, Frank, and Karl come through the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How'd your baptizin' go?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It went real good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's good. It's about time to eat and you know what I'm cravin'? Some of that take out chicken. Why don't you run get some of it, honey, for lunch?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would y'all like that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I guess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes ma'am. I like a fried chicken leg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, y'all gonna go with me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naw, hell, let them stay here with me and do men things. There might be some kind of ball game on we can watch. You go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be back in a little bit then. She leaves and Doyle walks up to Karl and Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I really just wanted to git your mama out of the house for a minute so we can have a talk. Y'all set down. They sit on the couch and Doyle kneels in front of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now here's the deal. Now that I'm gonna throw my entire life away doin' what I want to come live here with y'all, we have to get a few things straight. See, Frank, me and you mama wouldn't have any problems if it wadn't for you. We'd never have a bad word between us. But since you do exist, if I'm gonna be here as the head of the household, we'll have to live by my rules. And my rules are you don't speak unless you're spoken to. Stay out of my way and do what a regular kid does. You're a weird little shit. I don't get you. So wake up. Face what they call reality. We're gonna be a family now. And it's my family. I'll be payin' the bills so you got me. But I ain't your daddy. You just treat me like I am. I'm the boss, okay. And the other thing is your friend Karl has to go. We can't have a normal family with him livin' in the garage and comin' in the bedroom at four in the mornin' with hammers and shit. See?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl can stay if he wants to. Mama said -- Doyle slaps him across the face and Karl grabs Doyle's arm. Doyle shakes him off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't hit that boy no more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You shut up you, fuckin' retard. Get your shit and get out of here. (to Frank) That was a wake-up slap, Frank. Remember. Reality, like I said. Don't forget any bit of what I said to you and we'll be fine. Frank jumps up and runs from the house and Doyle sits back in his chair and pops a beer. Karl gets up and goes to the garage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl ties his books up with his strap and gets a bag from his bed and leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl is walking away as Linda pulls up in her car and gets out with fast-food bags.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you goin', Karl? Didn't you want some chicken and things?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No ma'am. I'm a'goin' off sommers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, okay. I got you some.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank, he went off, too. He ain't gonna be in there when you get indoors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where'd he go? What's goin' on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wanted to go off and play, I reckon. (pause) You go in there and you and that Doyle eat ye dinner. You don't have to worry yourself none.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right then. Well, I'll see you later. If you see Frank, tell him to come on back home. I don't get to see him all day except Sundays. He can play tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ma'am?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a good mama to that boy. You care for him. You work hard fer him to take care of him. You light him up in his eyes, I've seen it. He wouldn't know what to do without ye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well thank you, hun. That's real good of you to say. I wouldn't know what to do without him either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've been real good to me, too. It ain't ever'body that'd make biscuits in the middle of the night. You and that boy has give me a good feelin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We sure like havin' you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank ye. (Karl walks away, then turns) I'm just getting around to tellin' you, but I fixed your warshin' machine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SECRET PLACE - DAY Frank is on the ground digging a trench in the dirt with a stick. He hears footsteps in the leaves and looks up and sees Karl coming toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Karl. How'd you know to come out here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knowed you'd be here. (Karl sits on the stump) What are you a-doin' digging with that stob?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just diggin'. (pause) I ain't ever gonna be happy now. Not with that son of a bitch movin' in for good. I wish me and you and Mama could just run away. But she said he would find us wherever we went. He's crazy. Sometimes I think it would of been better if I wadn't ever born.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm glad of it you was borned. (pause) I reckon I ain't gonna be there in the garage no more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have to Karl. You have to look out for me. You don't let that son of a bitch run you off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're just a boy. You ort not to use that sort of language.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl, I ain't tryin' to say nothin' bad about you, but why don't you stop Doyle when he gets that away? You're older than him. You're strong, too. My daddy wouldn't let him do that to me and Mama.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That feller's a whole sight meaner than me. He'd just whup the tar out of me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I guess so. I'm real tired, you know that. A kid my age shouldn't be tired of things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm tired, too, Frank. (pause) If I ain't around no more, it don't mean I don't care fer ye. I care for ye a good deal. I care for you more than anybody they is. We made friends right off the bat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I care for you, too. But you'll be around, don't say that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hit don't make no difference where I was to be. We'll always be friends. There ain't no way to stop that. (pause) I aim for you to have these books. He hands him the books.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe you can make more sense out of them than I can. I made you a little old book marker and stuck it in that book on Christmas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't want to give away all your books.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I aim fer you to have 'em.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Man. Thanks. (pause) You know when you get a feelin' and you don't know why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got a feelin' today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reckon what kind of a feelin'?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like something different. I don't know. (pause) You're leavin' ain't you, Karl?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will ye do somethin' for me if I ast you to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know I would. Whatever you want.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't go home tonight and stay with that Doyle. He's got it in for ye tonight. I got me a feelin', too. Feels like to me you ort not be there in that house with him liquored up and mean. Ye mama neither. When you get up from here, I want you to go to that feller's house. Your mama's friend. I want you to give me your word on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. I give you my word. Is ever'thing gonna be okay? Are you all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ever'thing's okay, boy. I kindly want to put my arm around ye for a minute and then I'm gonna go on and leave here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Karl lays his arm on Frank's shoulder and Frank puts his hand on Karl's arm. They sit like that for a few moments, then Karl gets up with his paper sack and walks away. Frank takes the book marker out of the Christmas book. It is just a folded piece of notebook paper. On it is written 'You will be happy.' He looks up at Karl who is now thirty yards away in the trees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl! Karl turns around and he and Frank stare at each other through the trees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl knocks on the door. After a moment, Vaughan answers in a pair of big shorts and a sweatshirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl, what are you doing here? Come in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ain't a-stayin'. I need to ast you fer a favor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This evenin' I want you to go get Mizz Wheatley and that Frank and have them stay with you tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong? Is everything okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That dern Doyle is in a bad way again with that drinkin' and bein' mean to folks. Will you give me your word you'll do it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, sure, okay. He hasn't hurt them, has he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Naw, not yet. (hands the bag to Vaughan) I want ye to give this to Mizz Wheatley. Hit ain't much, but maybe there's a little somethin' to hep out. Hits what I've earned fixin' lawnmowers and whatnot fer Bill Cox. Vaughan takes the bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about you, Karl? Do you want to stay here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't reckon you have to go with women to be a daddy to a boy. (pause) You've been real square dealin' with me. The Bible says two men ort not lay together. But I'll bet you the Good Lord wouldn't send nobody like you to Hades. Some folks calls it Hell, I call it Hades. (Karl starts away) That boy lives inside of his own heart. Hits an awful big place. You take care of that boy. Vaughan watches Karl walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl stares at the bus station door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl stares at the house from the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl stares into the river.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl has a lawnmower blade sharpening it on a grinding wheel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Karl carrying the blade walks onto the porch and enters the living room.
direction.name: direction
